description: This course will focus on nineteenth-century American writings that, in the decades before the Civil
War, concern themselves with the issues of freedom, self-determination, and self-reliance.  Writing
during the period we often call the "American Renaissance," some of these authors embraced the idea
of literary independence for American writers, spiritual liberation form the religious institutions
of the past, and the opportunity for unlimited development of the self.  Others were concerned with
the possibilities of freedom from slavery, from marriage, or from economic oppression.  But all of
these writers can be seen as entering into a conversation or debate with one another about the
possibilities--or lack thereof--of attaining personal freedom and reforming American life.  Among
the texts we will consider: Emerson's Essays, Thoreau's Walden, Stowe's Uncle
Tom's Cabin, Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter, Frederick Douglass's Narrative of
the Life, Harriet Jacob's Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl, Fuller's "The Great
Lawsuit," Melville's "Bartleby the Scrivener" and "Benito Cereno," and Whitman's powtry.
Prerequisite: English 185 plus one additional course of relevant background.
